content.title: Superica, the new temple of relaxed Tex Mex cuisine

introduction.small: As the birthplace of fajitas, there is no shortage of Tex Mex restaurants in Houston. However, famous restauranteur Ford Fry's reputation shall undoubtedly make a difference.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Superica, the new temple of relaxed Tex Mex cuisine

paragraphs.text:
Located in a small cast iron stove factory that has been entirely renovated, Superica soon was on a roll. The setting is pleasant and the recipes well established, as the chef owns several other addresses in Atlanta and one in Charlotte. On the menu, comfort food with nacho chips, fajitas, tamales and chili con queso. Dishes born in the 1940s when traditional Northern Mexican food collided with the spiced up culinary habits of Texas ranchers. They are best paired with a Matador, the restaurant's pineapple and coriander-based signature margarita. As for the firewood-grilled meats, they are unanimously praised. Wine lovers will not be left out, as the list offers Chilean, Argentinean and Californian greats. And for your next visit, remember to pay La Lucha a visit, the chef's other restaurant located at the same address !

Superica
1801 North Shepherd Drive
Houston, TX 77008

+1 713 955 3215

www.superica.com

Menu : around 40 USD

content.title: Bisou, the new elegant and glamourous hotspot in River Oaks

introduction.small: With a contemporary spirit enhanced with the use of white stone and brass, Lyon chef Frédéric Perrier's new address is a surprising location, at once posh and trendy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bisou, the new elegant and glamourous hotspot in River Oaks

paragraphs.text:
Imagined and conceptualised by the Clé Group, this new address has to be experienced. Known for his innovative American cuisine with French overtones, Frédéric Perrier has steadily been challenging himself to reach new inventive heights. From starters onwards, tone is set with a will to amaze. Carrying both fish and meat, the menu offers a display of surprising flavours. It holds various original propositions, such as the rack of lamb served with goat cheese, or the yellowtail sashimi and pan seared foie gras with apple butter and Lillet. Follow your meal or pair dinner with cocktails that will undoubtedly win you over, as well as the champagne list that includes renowned producers and excellent vintages. Lively and fun Sunday brunches have already become an institution, just like Wednesday “friends” dinners.

Bisou
4444 Westheimer Rd Suite A-120,
Houston, TX 77027

+1 713 955 3855

www.bisourestaurant.com/

Menu : around 60 USD

content.title: The alliance of Southern spirit and 1960s chic

introduction.small: Renovated very recently, the White Hall is an urban and chic hotel, with postmodern overtones, and ideally located in the heart of the business district.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The alliance of Southern spirit and 1960s chic

paragraphs.text:
This historical address was the first 4-star hotel ever built in the State of Texas, in 1963. The White Hall welcomed various celebrities such as Elvis, Bob Dylan, Led Zeppelin and former president Barack Obama. If the facade has been entirely revamped, several elements of the original design have been retained, including the original white Italian marble floors and the floating spiral staircase that links the first and second floors. The 259 rooms cultivate a 1960s style, with a touch of contemporaneity. They have all been generously oversized and equipped with the latest technology. Do not miss the swimming pool, rearranged and showcasing a very original zigzagging shape. Located on the second floor, it also offers an unobstructed view over the city centre. Before or after a dip, a visit to the very trendy Part & Parcel is also a must. The restaurant's “hand-crafted” cocktails draw the crowds in during happy hour.

White Hall
1700 Smith St
Houston, TX 77002

+1 713 739 8800

www.thewhitehallhouston.com

Rooms: from 169 USD

content.title: Theodore Rex's modern bistro

introduction.small: In Houston, the Theodore Rex restaurant offers bistronomical food of tantalising originality, between regional recipes and European inspiration.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Theodore Rex's modern bistro

paragraphs.text:
Staff nicknamed it the “T-Rex”, even though you should not expect the shadow of a dinosaur in this casual-style restaurant. Along the wall is a bench seat, on which blue, white and red triangles have been weaved. Overhead lights seem to be floating above, like bubbles of soap hanged in the air for a moment in time. Justin Yu, renowned Houston chef, unveils his modern bistro named “Theodore Rex”. The menu offers European-inspired cuisine, so you will not be surprised to find a “Paris-Brest” dessert or a stracciatella soup on it. In the plate, the chef favours simplicity and highlights regional products.
Choose tomato toasts, somehow between a bruschetta and a Catalan tomato bread – regulars rave about it. Keep up with a Texas wagyu shaved loin, before a sweet milk chocolate ice cream, with candied almonds and apple butter. It is recommended to book a table beforehand, as the restaurant is always crowded.

Theodore Rex
1302 Nance Street Unit A
Houston, TX 77002

+1 832 830 8592

www.trexhouston.com ﻿

Menu: around 32 USD

content.title: Mixing art and beer at the Beer Can House, it is indeed possible!

introduction.small: The Beer Can House includes 50,000 flattened or cut-up beer cans, a work John Martin Milkovisch created to decorate his house. Visit of a veritable house of metal.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mixing art and beer at the Beer Can House, it is indeed possible!

paragraphs.text:
A retired upholsterer from the Southern Pacific Railroad, John Martin Milkovisch began covering the facade of his house with beer cans in 1968. The owner of the Beer Can House in Houston just wished to pleasantly pass the time. The artistic dimension of the place was quickly noticed: beer cans, metal trinkets and pieces of aluminium merged harmoniously into a giant and habitable sculpture.

Upon John's death, his wife Mary took to offering tours of the surrealist work of art for a few dollars, and it quickly became one of the main attractions of the region. Purchased and restored by the Orange Show Foundation, the house is still open to an audience eager to discover the unusual sights of Texas.

The Beer Can House
222 Malone Street
Houston

+1 713 926 6368

www.visithoustontexas.com

content.title: Helen Greek, a tasty trip to Mount Olympus

introduction.small: In the heart of Houston, this restaurant offers Greek wine and food in a warm, family atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Helen Greek, a tasty trip to Mount Olympus

paragraphs.text:
Filotimo is a Greek word that means “doing well”, all the while taking care of one's neighbour. This is the credo adopted by the smiling team at Helen Greek Food and Wine, always at your service. The red brick walls, mirrors and high ceilings make you think of an authentic tavern where the spirit of Greek gods still lingers. Here, traditional recipes are based on local products sourced from the Gulf of Mexico. On the menu, you'll find vegetable and cheese tarts, marinated anchovies and grilled cauliflower with sesame lemon sauce.
The selection of wines, also Hellenic, is truly impressive. The menu opens with two quotations: one from Greek author Homer, the other from cartoon star Homer Simpson, each praising in its own way the merits of the nectar of the gods. If you do not know what to choose, the staff will advise you on the perfect wine that best suits your dish.

Helen Greek Food and Wine
2429 Rice Boulevard
Houston, TX 77005

+1 832-831-7133

www.helengreek.com

Menu: around 30 USD

content.title: Space Center Houston: “Apollo, do you read me?”

introduction.small: The Space Center takes you behind the scenes of NASA programs. Learn about space exploration, the life of astronauts who changed the game and projects for our future.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Space Center Houston: “Apollo, do you read me?”

paragraphs.text:
As soon as you enter Mission Control, you find yourself plunged in the 1960s, golden age of the American Space Program. President Kennedy had expressed his wish to see man walk on the moon, and funded a space program for the first astronaut to do so to be American. Mission accomplished!

The Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center is located about 18 miles from Houston. Built in 1962, it serves as ground control for human space flight programs. 30 years later, the centre opened part of its facilities to the general public.

In this place, unique in the world, you can admire a wonderful collection of moon rocks and lunar samples, and even witness the preparation astronauts go through in a huge swimming pool that reproduces the conditions of space travel. You can also discover the latest technical innovations that may, some day, allow man to set foot on Mars.

Space Center Houston
1601 NASA Road 1
77058 Houston

+1 281 244 2100

www.spacecenter.org

content.title: Gourmet Houston

introduction.small: The Houston Culinary Tour calls for an alternative visit of the city, accompanied by a restaurant chef.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gourmet Houston

paragraphs.text:
The streets of Houston are riddled with thousands of restaurants, from now famous food trucks to gourmet restaurants run by the greatest chefs. The city's cultural melting pot gives visitors an almost endless choice of food, from steakhouses to seafood restaurants and Japanese, Vietnamese, Mexican and French specialities…

Gastronomy is a reflection of the Houston population, multiple and mixed. It is possible to discover each district of the city while doing a gourmet tour, going for architectural and cultural points of interest while making a few stops in some of the must-go-to restaurants, markets and bars the metropolis has to offer. Among the different tours available, we would recommend the Downtown Food Tour, the Montrose Food Tour and the Height Food Tour. Some chefs also offer thematic tours, based on chocolate products, or woman-run establishments for instance.

www.visithoustontexas.com/culinary-tours

content.title: Magnolia Hotel: stay in historic downtown Houston

introduction.small: In the core of downtown, the Magnolia Hotel sets a meeting with the city history, in an elegant and modern atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Magnolia Hotel: stay in historic downtown Houston

paragraphs.text:
Built in 1926, the 22-floor building was first used as the Houston Post Dispatch and later as the headquarters for the Shell Oil Company. Over the years, the city grew around it, glass towers pushing through. Opened in 2003, the hotel hugely benefits from its location, in the core of downtown, less than ten minutes from the Minute Maid Park and the Downtown Aquarium by foot, and also ten minutes from the Museum District by car.

From the hotel rooftop, you can jump into a Jacuzzi and gaze at the urban skyline, a beautiful show especially when night falls. On lower floors, the design is contemporary and the atmosphere cosy with dark wood panels on the walls, leather armchairs and here and there touches of bright colours. As an extra, lovely bookshelves are at your disposal at the Magnolia Hotel when you feel the need to take a break between two city visits. As for the Lounge restaurant, it offers snacks for lunch, and burgers or filet mignon for dinner. Room service is available 24/7 for those who prefer to remain in their cocoon.

Magnolia Hotel
1100 Texas Avenue
77002 Houston

+1 713 221 0011

www.magnoliahotels.com/houston

Rooms: from 179 USD

content.title: Houston Galleria, shopping paradise

introduction.small: A city within the city, Houston Galleria will fulfill every window shopping addict.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Houston Galleria, shopping paradise

paragraphs.text:
Over 210,000 m², Houston Galleria welcomes 24 million visitors each year. It is the biggest mall of all Texas, so you'd better look up the mall map first! Built in 1970, it has recently been enlarged and houses more than 375 shops of all kinds in its midst, so that you are bound to find what you are looking for. Among them, classic shops like Abercrombie & Fitch, Zara and Gap as well as retail chains like Macy's and Saks Fifth Avenue open their doors to you. You will also find a large number of luxury boutiques like Gucci, Chanel, Louis Vuitton and Fendi.

An entire floor is devoted to food where you can have lunch in one the 30 mall restaurants, and even get a hotel room there as it accommodates two hotels: the Weston Oaks and the Westin Galleria. In great American tradition, shopping also goes hand in hand with sports and entertainment, as the centre offers a rink and two swimming pools.

The Galleria
5085 Westheimer Road
77056 Houston

+1 713 966 3500

www.simon.com/mall/the-galleria

content.title: Memorial Park: between nature and history

introduction.small: In the heart of West Houston, Memorial Park offers a wonderful recreational and cultural land over 600 hectares.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Memorial Park: between nature and history

paragraphs.text:
Memorial Park is Houston's largest public urban park, heaven for athletes who can take their pick between tennis, 18 hole golf, swimming, croquet, volleyball and skating. In the morning, you are likely to come across joggers you take advantage of the fresh atmosphere to run along the Seymour Lieberman path, an equipped fitness trail of 2.5 miles.

For lunch, you'll find families gathering over at Memorial Park Picnic Loop. In the evening right before sunset, you can recharge your batteries and breathe some fresh air in the woods. But if you pay attention to the history of the park, you'll notice it actually is a place of reverence. Soldiers during WW1 came to practice before being sent to the front. Today, is serves as Memorial to the dead.

Memorial Park
Washington Avenue
77007 Houston

+1 713 863 8403

www.memorialparkconservancy.org

content.title: The Inn at Chachalaca Bend: surrounded by lush greenery

introduction.small: To enjoy this natural oasis, you have to head to Los Fresnos, only a few minutes' drive from the beautiful beaches of South Padre Island.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Inn at Chachalaca Bend: surrounded by lush greenery

paragraphs.text:
If you want to avoid motels without charm, or if you prefer the luxury of quiet homes to crowded resorts, the Chachalaca Bend is for you. Located in Los Fresnos, less than 30 minutes from South Padre Island Highway, this small inn is set between a forest of palm and olive trees and Resaca Las Antonias Lake. With only five beautiful rooms, it is best to book well in advance.

Outside, the beautiful garden is a refuge for birds of the region. Small nests are installed all around the domain and, at dawn, the sound of birds singing will be your only alarm. You can then enjoy the hot breakfast prepared every morning by the hosts. To better enjoy the natural setting, the owners have built peaceful niches all around the property. Here, a clearing lit by fairy lights, there a pontoon by the lake on which there are red rocking chairs. Here you will enjoy southern living at its finest!

The Inn at Chachalaca Bend
36298 Chachalaca Bend
78566 Los Fresnos

+1 956 233 1180

www.chachalaca.com

Rooms: from 159 USD

content.title: Last Concert Cafe: live music and Tex-Mex cuisine

introduction.small: The Last Concert Cafe hides its game behind a discreet red door: every night of the week, this Tex-Mex restaurant vibrates to the sound of live music.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Last Concert Cafe: live music and Tex-Mex cuisine

paragraphs.text:
Once you have crossed the patio of the building, you're already in Mexico. Within moments, the little white house with red doors turns into a festive place, decorated with garlands and colourful mosaics. Do not be surprised if the menu offers only Mexican specialties, like the delicious nachos with beef and chicken, guacamole, chili and cheddar, or quesadillas topped with a choice of chicken, shrimp, cheese or guacamole, without forgetting the savoury fajitas and enchiladas.

Open for lunch and brunch, it offers specialties for you to enjoy in front of a live concert every night. The best bands in Houston flock there to play on the small stage of the restaurant or, in fine weather, on the beautiful outdoor terrace. And if, on a Monday night, you decide it is time to embark on a career as an artist, push open the door of the restaurant. Monday evenings are ‘Open Mike' so you can get up on stage to sing, play an instrument, recite poetry or do a one-(wo)man show.

Last Concert Cafe
1403 Nance Street
77002 Houston

+1 713 226 8563

www.lastconcert.com

Menu: around 20 USD

content.title: Look at the sky at the James Turrell Skyspace

introduction.small: To enjoy a unique sensory and visual experience, architect James Turrell installed his Twilight Epiphany on the Rice University campus.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Look at the sky at the James Turrell Skyspace

paragraphs.text:
The installation is located near the Shepherd School of Music on Main Street and does not go unnoticed. It is a pyramid of concrete, stone and steel, almost entirely covered with grass. An opening in the roof forces a deluge of light into the construction. Its creator James Turrell loves to play with light and space. Since the 1970s, dozens of skyspaces have come up from the ground in the United States, but also in Europe and in Japan.

The concept is quite simple: at each sunrise and sunset, a LED system projects light onto the pyramid's roof. Visitors can therefore admire the interaction of natural and artificial lights. The construction is also an experimental lab for students of the music school, who sometimes invade the premises at night to enjoy incredible acoustics. You can check the sequences time schedule on the monument website.

James Turell Skyspace Twilight Epiphany
Rice University Campus
77005 Houston

+1 713 348 4758

www.skyspace.rice.edu

content.title: Derek Hotel: Texas chic

introduction.small: As the only independent hotel of downtown Houston, the Derek relies on elegance and design whilst retaining its Texan roots.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Derek Hotel: Texas chic

paragraphs.text:
Located in the Uptown district, the recently renovated hotel may hold both 1970s and contemporary overtones, but most of all exudes glamour. It was named after the oil derricks that dress up the Texan landscape. However, you are here as far as you can from the ranches and cow-boys clichés, even though there's a twist on some stereotypical figures like that multicoloured bull statue in the hotel lobby, mounted with the Lone Star Flag and the logo of the hotel.

Hotel Derek opts in favour of colour, of vivid tones preferably. From the bedrooms to the meeting spaces and the restaurant, shades multiply and give energy to the interior design. Among those you can spot a fuchsia signature chair, a bright red sofa, yellow and turquoise fabrics as well as sequined and ornamented bull statuettes, once again a wink to this tweaked folklore.

The hotel is comprised of 312 rooms and a restaurant – the Revolve Kitchen & Brew during breakfast and lunch hours, and the Revolve Bar as soon as night falls to enjoy cocktails or a glass of wine, and play a game of snooker.

Derek Hotel
2525 West Loop South
77027 Houston

+1 713 961 3000

www.hotelderek.com

Rooms: from 130 USD

content.title: Bistro Menil: European-inspired

introduction.small: The Bistro Menil welcomes you at any time of day to enjoy bistro cuisine inspired by chef Greg Martin's travels in France, Italy and Spain.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bistro Menil: European-inspired

paragraphs.text:
European bistro cuisine is revisited with taste, elegance and, above all, an unfailing love for quality products. Just steps from the Menil Collection - the famous Museum of Contemporary Art - this 2.0 bistro plays on design. Without ostentation, the decor is refined, the concrete floors contrasting with the plain wooden tables, and white and anthracite grey tones.

On the menu, you will be spoiled for choice: appetizers, pizzas, quiches, salads, risottos or, more surprisingly, cassoulet - all gluten-free. The wines offered à la carte were all selected by the chef during his travels in California, Argentina and Europe. As for the beers, they are obviously craft brewed from Houston or Austin. Feel free to come during Happy Hour, after visiting the museum. The chef offers a selection of tapas (grilled eggplant, fried squid or Serrano ham), accompanied by a glass of wine or a cocktail.

Bistro Menil
1513 West Alabama Street
77006 Houston

+1 713 904 3537

www.bistromenil.com

Menu: around 25 USD

content.title: Starry-eyed at Houston Ballet

introduction.small: Created in 1955, Houston Ballet has become one of the major classical ballet companies in the United States.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Starry-eyed at Houston Ballet

paragraphs.text:
Houston is a city of culture and shows. It attracts artists and craftsmen in various fields and provides for the best plays, operas and museums of all kinds. Delusion of grandeurs? Maybe... Still, when you are in town, there is no way to be bored and you are likely to struggle with that scheduling of so many activities.

If you fancy a gala reception, go to Preston Street at the Houston Ballet Center for Dance to see classical ballet performances. The company is considered to be one of the very best in the United States, and programmed three ballets for the 2016/2017 season: Madame Butterfly, Cinderella and La Bayadère. It often programs must-sees like Romeo and Juliet or The Nutcracker, which are accessible for all ages.

Houston Ballet is also a world-renowned dance school. Upcoming talents come from everywhere to learn and improve their craft in dance halls before, one day, performing on stage in front of mesmerized spectators.

Houston Ballet Center for Dance
601 Preston Street
77002 Houston

+1 713 523 6300

www.houstonballet.org

content.title: Marriott Westchase: between The Galleria and Chinatown

introduction.small: Less than 20 minutes from the city centre, the Marriott Westchase offers a premium experience for the tightest budgets.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Marriott Westchase: between The Galleria and Chinatown

paragraphs.text:
Like Houston itself, this hotel is huge and sprawling. The Marriott Westchase has 600 spacious and comfortable rooms, all set around an enormous atrium in which you will find the ‘Atrium Lobby Bar'. The Marriott group takes pleasure in adapting the decoration of its hotels to the spirit of the region, so the atmosphere here is Texan, but no frills. Slightly outside the city centre, the hotel is close to The Galleria, the largest mall in the city, and not far from Chinatown, where you can taste delicious dim sum or attend a tea ceremony. Guided visits to the neighbourhood are organized by the tourist office.
A very welcome extra, the hotel has a fitness centre and two pools, one inside and one outside, ideal for cooling off after a long day of sightseeing. Dining options include a buffet that is available for breakfast, a café, and two restaurants, open all day, offering the best of Texan cuisine.

Houston Mariott Westchase
2900 Briarpark Drive
77042 Houston

+1 713 978 7400

www.marriott.fr/hotels/travel/houwm-houston-marriott-westchase

Rooms: from 85 USD

content.title: Houston Grand Opera, the temple of classical music

introduction.small: Created 60 years ago, the small company turned into an opera reference of national calibre.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Houston Grand Opera, the temple of classical music

paragraphs.text:
From its creation in 1955, the Houston Grand Opera on Preston Street has built its reputation on offering a unique program, modern and diversified. Until 1987, performances took place in the heart of Downtown at Jones Hall, but they have moved to Wortham Center, a magnificent and brand new opera house located only minutes from the old one.

The company offers all sorts of operatic performances from the more classical ones like Faust or a Wagner Cycle to new productions encompassing modern American history like Jackie O., Nixon in China and Harvey Milk. We can also mention an adaptation of Saint-Exupéry's The Little Prince and the first Spanish-language opera Florencia en el Amazonas, presented in two acts and taking inspiration from Gabriel Garcia Márquez's magical realism. To know more about the current program, please visit the company's own website.

Houston Grand Opera
510 Preston Street
77002 Houston

+1 713 228 6737

www.houstongrandopera.org

content.title: Pastry War: the bar where agave is king

introduction.small: This Downtown mezcaleria brings you into the warm and festive ambiance of Mexico with a decor that hints at the ‘day of the dead'.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pastry War: the bar where agave is king

paragraphs.text:
A little reminder for the uninitiated: agave is a succulent plant from which syrups and alcohols are extracted, including tequila and mescal. Bobby Heugel and Alba Huerta, the owners of the bar, have travelled around the agave producing areas of Mexico to find small family distilleries and have selected the best of their production.

The Pastry War is named after a five-month conflict in 1838 about unpaid debts involving the French and the Mexicans. At the Pastry War, you will find no pastry, but instead, a multitude of mescal cocktails and tequila, such as the “Lobito” – rum, averna, lemon, blood orange and damiana flowers – or the “Chota” – white tequila, tamarind and grapefruit. In addition to a nice selection of spirits and beers, you can also enjoy Mexican specialties: cheese but also tamales, a small sweet or savoury corn bread that is steamed.

Pastry War
310 Main Street
77002 Houston

+1 713 225 3310

www.thepastrywar.com

From around 9 USD per cocktail

content.title: Spend a night on a ranch

introduction.small: To live a genuine experience amidst Texan land, you have to get out of Houston. An hour by car is enough to reach the Texas Ranch Life. That is a change of scenery!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Spend a night on a ranch

paragraphs.text:
Swallowed by the tumultuous urban life, we tend to forget that Texas is a land of pioneers and big spaces. The Lone Star State knows how to pay tribute to that simpler life, and this is the lifestyle you will enjoy while staying at the Texas Ranch Life. In this vast land of 700 hectares, cow-boys raise cattle in the fashion of yesteryears, drive the Longhorn cows using the lasso like no one else and ride their horses unto the sunset. You're only one step away from a John Wayne movie!

The owners have set up eight lodges in small wooden houses from the 1850s, and they can welcome anyone from couples to large families. Rest assured, every modern appliance is at your disposal inside. The interior design is cleverly conceived and the atmosphere as welcoming as can be. When the night falls and you can hear cattle in the distance, you will really feel the essence of Far West.

Texas Ranch Life
10848 Cactus Lane
77426 Chappell Hill

+1 979 865 3649

www.texasranchlife.com

Rooms: from 184 USD

content.title: Contemporary Arts Museum Houston: art in motion

introduction.small: With innovative temporary exhibitions, learning programs for all and upcoming talents regularly put in the spotlight, the Contemporary Arts Museum shines through the whole city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Contemporary Arts Museum Houston: art in motion

paragraphs.text:
Always fresh, always free is the museum's motto. The goal is simple: promoting contemporary art and shedding a light on the relation between our dynamic and innovative current society and the art renewal in Houston. It is located in a surprising building in the heart of the museum district: a stainless steel parallelogram designed by architect Gunnar Birkerts, whom is already well know for numerous constructions in the States of Kansas, Michigan and New York.

The Contemporary Arts Museum opened in 1972. It renews exhibition shows every six weeks and sets a goal in discovering upcoming talents, where they find a space to display their work, hence promoting contemporary art at regional, national and even international levels.

CAMH endeavours to be a place of exchange. Lectures are programmed all year long, and since the museum is meant for a large audience, creative workshops are available to children.

Contemporary Arts Museum Houston
5216 Montrose Boulevard
77006 Houston

+1 713 284 8250

camh.org

content.title: Rodeo, national sport

introduction.small: In Texas, everything is a call back to the conquest of the West. Do not miss rodeo shows, a shining star.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Rodeo, national sport

paragraphs.text:
Put on your Stetson, a pair of jeans and a plaid shirt. You are almost in the skin of a cow-boy. You still have to try your hand at rodeo, which actually brings together three major disciplines: Bronc Riding in which the rider tries to climb a horse that attempts to throw them off, Bull riding in which a rider attempts to stay mounted on the animal, and if you prefer to keep your feet firmly on the ground Roping consists in capturing calves with a looped rope called lasso. With a little bit of skill and courage, you may just become the last heir of those first farmers of the American West.

In Houston and the surrounding area, several ranches offers beginner classes and you will easily find all the gear you need in specialist shops. In all of Texas, there is no way around rodeo, and you will have plenty of choice amongst all the tournaments and shows that are organised everywhere. And if you are in Houston in March, hurry to the Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo, the largest event of the kind in the United States. The program consists of rodeo contests, concerts, giant barbecues and much more! Twenty unforgettable days of celebration.

Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo
3 NRG Parkway
77054 Houston

+1 832 667 1000

www.rodeohouston.com

content.title: ICON takes you back to the early 20th century

introduction.small: Set in a landmark building, ICON Hotel enjoys a rebirth and welcomes guests for a stay between charm and elegance.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: ICON takes you back to the early 20th century

paragraphs.text:
The ICON Hotel building stands tall in the northern part of Downtown Houston. Built in 1911, it had a prior life as the Union National Bank, one of the very first steel and concrete skyscrapers of the entire country. Inside, some period elements pop up and take you back to the early days of the previous century. The former safe has been kept in, dial phones are used as decoration tools and velvet chairs and huge marble columns are everywhere to be found.

The 135 rooms of the hotel offer a rather classical decoration and a magnificent view onto Houston. At the hotel bar, L&L, the cocktail selection ranges from classics to contemporary creations, beers are brewed in the Houston area and the wine list offers a sophisticated selection of Californian and Argentinean productions. As for the restaurant, it is open for lunch dinner hours and offers Texan dishes of course!

Hotel ICON
220 Main Street
77002 Houston

+1 713 224 4266

www.hotelicon.com

Rooms: from 130 USD

content.title: See the Houston Rockets play

introduction.small: Home to the Rockets, Houston's basketball team, the Toyota Center also offers exceptional shows.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: See the Houston Rockets play

paragraphs.text:
In Houston like everywhere in the USA, there is no way around NBA games. If you are lucky enough to be in the tribunes, watch the spectators with attention as the biggest followers collect jerseys of their favourite team. The Rockets' are red (sometimes also grey or black, depending on their adversaries). Whether you are a fan of the Rockets or not though, it is courtside that the show goes on.

Living up to its reputation, the NBA league offers shows that only the USA know how to deliver with cheerleaders, music, and large screens. The Rockets are no different.
The team has seen its day in the 1980s, even though the McGrady/Ming double act made the sports headlines in the 2000s. Today, the Toyota Center also welcomes the Houston Aeros, the hockey team, a sport less talked about in the rest of the world, but just as spectacular.

Toyota Center Arena
1510 Polk Street
77002 Houston

www.houstontoyotacenter.com

content.title: Learn and play at the Museum of Natural Science

introduction.small: Each year, Houston's most attended museum welcomes more than two million visitors, of all ages.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Learn and play at the Museum of Natural Science

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of Hermann Park in the Museum District, the Houston Museum of Natural Science spreads over four floors and expects to expand in the coming years. It is one of the country's most attended museums, so vast that guides recommend you organise a two-day visit. With a little bit of planning and selecting your points of interest, one day might just be enough.

The museum is divided into thematic exhibit areas offering a variety of activities. A planetarium to admire the wonders of the universe, an IMAX Screen theatre to watch different 3D movies and documentaries, areas devoted to dinosaurs, the African continent, a palaeontology gallery, and multitudes of rooms on oil and gas, minerals and precious stones. The museum also sports interest in Amerindian cultures, from the Andes to the Arctic. This cultural centre is sure to delight your kids.

Museum of Natural Science
5555 Hermann Park Drive
77030 Houston

+1 713 639 4629

www.hmns.org

content.title: Seaside stop in Galveston

introduction.small: Less than an hour from Houston, Galveston offers sandy beaches riddled with Victorian houses. It resembles the dream islands of many American TV series.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Seaside stop in Galveston

paragraphs.text:
The damages caused by hurricane Ike are no more than a far away memory. The island is born again and has regained its past glory. Inhabitants can tell you, the story of Galveston has always been linked to hurricanes. First the one that struck in 1900 and then Ike in 2008. Still, tourists did not abandon that piece of land located in the Gulf of Mexico, on the contrary. This quiet island brings happiness to the families that choose to come lazing about.

Blue waters and palm trees are constant reminders you are on holiday. You may find a rental on the seafront to listen to the sounds of crashing waves at night, or downtown in a Victorian house turned guest house if you prefer. Regarding museums and outings, do not miss Moody Gardens and its three pyramids, devoted to sea life, tropical worlds and space research.

www.galveston.com

content.title: San Jacinto Battleground: a site filled with History

introduction.small: Lovers of American and especially Texan History, take note! The San Jacinto Battleground State Historic Site is a true marvel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: San Jacinto Battleground: a site filled with History

paragraphs.text:
About 25 miles from Houston, where the Buffalo Bayou River flows into the San Jacinto Bay, you will find a site completely devoted to the glory of Texas. In 1836, this small piece of land became part of the History of the State in just a few minutes when Texas revolutionaries fought the Mexican Army for their Independence.

About 100 years later, in 1939, the State built a memorial that you can now visit: a 567-feet-high obelisk, mounted with a star. You can climb up the monument onto the observation floor, or simply visit the museum on ground floor.

Reenactments of the battle are performed each year in April. If you want to know more about the history of Texas, you can also visit the USS Texas, a warship used during WW1 and WW2, now moored on site and completely turned into a museum.

San Jacinto Battleground State Historic Site
3523 Independence Parkway
77571 La Porte

+1 281 479 2421

www.sanjacinto-museum.org

content.title: Go to a baseball game

introduction.small: Two steps from Downtown Houston, Minute Maid Park is the Astros' official stadium, one of the most prominent baseball teams at the moment.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Go to a baseball game

paragraphs.text:
In the United States, every major city has to own a baseball team, if possible one that plays in the MLB, Major League of Baseball. Houston is no different, as it offers home to the Astros. If the team does not hold the New York Yankees or San Francisco Giants records, the Astros do fiercely defend their colours and their stadium, the Minute Maid Park, which is nationally renowned.

Take a guided tour of the ballpark and get behind the scenes. Still, is there a best way to really feel the atmosphere of the stadium than to watch the game from the terraces? Do not be surprised, hot-dog breaks are many and it is unusual to see spectators remain in their seat for more than 15 minutes. Baseball season starts in April and ends in October. Get your tickets fast!

Minute Maid Park

77002 Houston

houston.astros.mlb.com/hou/ballpark/index.jsp

content.title: Gatlin's BBQ: Texas ribs

introduction.small: Houston is full of excellent barbecue restaurants. Among them, Gatlin's, which above all, is a family affair.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gatlin's BBQ: Texas ribs

paragraphs.text:
Everyone agrees about certain restaurants, and Gatlin's BBQ is one of them. The darling of the public and the media, it has already won the Houston Press Barbecue Award twice, awarded by ‘The Houston Press', a free cultural weekly. Regulars come for the welcome, which is unlike any other, while those new to the restaurant come back for its culinary expertise.

Gatlin's serves barbecue sauce grilled spareribs - ribs - in every imaginable way: in salads, sandwiches or in a ‘spicy' version. It also offers a deliciously tender beef brisket – the house specialty – or recipes from Louisiana, all accompanied by amazing baked potatoes. Over and above the content of your plates, you will be charmed by its rustic setting. Greg Gatlin and his parents have recently moved into their new location on Ella Boulevard, which is six times larger than the old premises, but also more convivial. So there's something to satisfy all of their many fans!

Gatlin's BBQ

content.title: State of Grace: an homage to Houston

introduction.small: In opening State of Grace, Chef Ford Fry has returned to his roots, paying tribute to his hometown by doing what he does best: cooking.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: State of Grace: an homage to Houston

paragraphs.text:
If you happen to bump into the prolific Ford Fry and question him on State of Grace, he will probably say that his restaurant is a place of connections: a place that is open to all where it is possible to come for a business dinner, or with friends or family. Ford Fry does not impose any constraints: according to him, life is above all "knowing how to have fun, being with the people we love, and enjoying a good meal”.

Fry, Texan born, lived in Atlanta for many years, where he runs ten restaurants, and opened State of Grace in 2015, right across from his old high school. So it is no accident if he likes to draw dishes from his childhood. The menu reflects all the eclecticism of Houston, from queso Oaxaca - a seafood dish with Mexican accents - to the traditional prime rib, and oysters, which have the reputation of being the best in town.

content.title: Living the cow-boy life

introduction.small: Come to George Ranch and discover more than 100 years of Texan history.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Living the cow-boy life

paragraphs.text:
The ranch is located in Richmond, about 30 miles South-West of Downtown Houston. To access it, get out of town, take road 59, then Crabb River Road and the way will be clearly indicated. The welcoming party will wait for you on an entrance porch, flanked with seemingly never-ending white fences. Dressed in period cloths, your hosts seem to come straight from the early 20th century. Women wear long dresses, and men bandanas, Stetson hats and dusters.

The different buildings of the Park spread over a vast domain of more than 23,000 acres. You can choose to visit a completely restored pioneers' farm, a beautiful Victorian manor and even a cattle ranch complex. Many activities have been thought of for you, including a cow-boy show with lasso demonstrations. You can take part in the life of the ranch and even help looking after the calves with the advice of wise cattlemen.

George Ranch Historical Park

content.title: The Granduca saga

introduction.small: The Granduca takes on from the Italian way of life and princely palazzi.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Granduca saga

paragraphs.text:
No one could guess what lies behind the ochre walls of this building riddled with palm trees. And yet, here is a hotel worthy of the greatest Renaissance villas. Heirs to an aristocratic Italian family, the owners run several hotels in the United States, including another one in Austin.

The Houston Granduca offers 122 rooms, which makes it a rather small hotel compared to the city standards. It pays tribute to Italia in the way of interior design, chandeliers and wrought iron beds, tapestries and family portraits hanging on the walls. The hotel also offers one of the best Italian restaurants of the city, Ristorante Cavour, which is inspired by northern Italian cuisine. On the menu, fresh pasta, prosciutto ham and a lovely Tuscany wine selection.

content.title: Full steam over Padre Island

introduction.small: Head to South Padre Island, a heavenly island of the Gulf of Mexico where everything is sweet, simple and natural.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Full steam over Padre Island

paragraphs.text:
In order to reach the island, you have to drive along the coast towards Corpus Christi then take Road 358. It will take you about four hours, but it is worth it. The island is true haven for lovers of getaways and the sand is the whitest you're ever going to find.

Though a little on the arty side, the south of Padre Island is the meeting point of surfers and other sea sport lovers. Beware the month of March because armies of students come over for their spring break. If you want peace, you would be better off at that period.

The rest of the year, you can hop a boat for some morning fishing, or ride a horse on the beach at sunset. Up North, you will find the exceptional Padre Island National Seashore nature reserve.

Padre Island

www.sopadre.com

content.title: La Maison in Midtown: European charm

introduction.small: Tucked in between the swarming streets of Downtown and the Museum District, La Maison, an intimate gem of a place, could be summarized in one sentence: ‘Welcome home'.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Maison in Midtown: European charm

paragraphs.text:
Midtown is considered to be one of the liveliest neighbourhoods of Houston: gourmets appreciate its restaurants and night owls alight in its trendy bars. Yet it is here that Genora Boykins and Sharon Owens decided to set up their small bed and breakfast of just seven rooms, an alternative for visitors seeking peace and privacy.

Inaugurated in 2010, the house is inspired by the architecture of the French Quarter of New Orleans. Outside you will find a small terrace, complete with rocking chairs from which you can admire the Downtown skyline. Like all authentic B&Bs, each room is different and tastefully decorated. A conference room can be found here as well because the owners wanted to provide services worthy of an upscale hotel. On the ground floor are the living room, the dining room for dinner, and the kitchen where you will be served a tasty breakfast with southern accents.

La Maison in Midtown

+1 713 529 3600

content.title: ZaZa: Boutique Hotel the Texas way

introduction.small: One of the trendiest hotels of all Houston, ZaZa Hotel cultivates a personal art of living, between excess and Texan charm.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: ZaZa: Boutique Hotel the Texas way

paragraphs.text:
This address pushes the limits of the American hotel trade, more used to large chains and huge resorts. It is probably because ZaZa has so much personality that it has become the favourite stop of many starlets and fashionistas over a few years. There may also be other reasons to explain the attraction: the perfect location right next to the Museum District, the hotel restaurant – which offers classic but fine cuisine, from beef tenderloin to chicken sandwiches, or the spa, fitness centre and swimming pool.

Deliberately flashy but never in bad taste, the 315 rooms the hotel counts all have their distinct and unique style, with leopard or zebra-printed fabrics in some, and huge crystal candelabras in others. Wonder at the look of the NASA and Rock Star suites, the Geisha House, or in more sober fashion, the Soho Loft and its brick wall. To better enjoy the vista onto the city, ask for a room on the higher floors.

ZaZa Hotel Houston
5701 Main Street

content.title: The Hay Merchant: an ‘arty' beer bar

introduction.small: Located in trendy Montrose, The Hay Merchant has a trendy setting and clientele, which they fully assume, as their sole ambition is to offer the best.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Hay Merchant: an ‘arty' beer bar

paragraphs.text:
In Houston, it is rumoured that Texas is the new Eldorado for craft beer. Microbreweries are multiplying and the hoppy beverage is becoming an excellent, highly sought after product. The Hay Merchant is a reflection of this new image of beer, far from stereotypes. Yeast, fermentation, temperature... all criteria are carefully scrutinized. The beer menu is primarily intended for connoisseurs but, rest assured, they take the time to advise you to help you choose, because talking about beer here is a passion as much as an expertise.

On the menu there are Sour Ales (rather tart beers), India Pale Ales (or IPA, which are quite hoppy), Belgian ales, amber ales... And since beer pairings are fashionable, the Hay Merchant offers a varied menu, which ranges from the Chili Dog – hot dog served with jalapeños – to the Beer Bathed Hot Dog – a spicy hot dog, accompanied by bacon, cheddar, red onions and mustard – and the Blackbird Cajun Meat Pies... ask your waiter for the recipe.

The Hay Merchant

content.title: Pinto Ranch, shopping Made in Texas

introduction.small: Pinto ranch is the Mecca for all rodeo lovers. “More than just western wear, Pinto Ranch is American lifestyle”.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pinto Ranch, shopping Made in Texas

paragraphs.text:
The shop smells of leather and country music reverberates everywhere. No wonder, you're in Texas. Here, everything is produced on the premises and articles available are always of the highest quality. Pinto Ranch is much more than a souvenir shop. Actually, it is quite well known by Texan rodeo lovers.

If you never know what to bring back from a trip, don't hesitate while in Houston and run to this shop! Of course, a saddle might just be too big for your luggage, but you could give in to genuine boots or a cow-boy hat. Everything is handcrafted, and it is said some rodeo champions buy from them. If you are looking for something a tad more discreet, you can always bring back a pair of jeans, a plaid shirt or jewellery from their own lovely collection.

Pinto Ranch

content.title: 13 Celsius: trendy wine bar

introduction.small: Right in the heart of Midtown, 13 Celsius has a sophisticated wine list, vintage décor, and a trendy clientele.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: 13 Celsius: trendy wine bar

paragraphs.text:
The name of the bar perfectly sums up the theme: 13 Celsius, i.e., the ideal temperature for storing wine. Amateurs and novices gather here around carefully selected wines from around the world – France, Italy, Spain, Germany, Australia and the best regions of the USA. In a decor reminiscent of a refurbished industrial warehouse, you can exchange with the bartender, who will be happy to recommend the wine of the moment or a classic vintage, according to your mood or desire.

If you are feeling peckish, 13 Celsius offers snacks at all hours, such as plates of cheese or cold cuts, a salad, a slice of pizza or pastry. The goal is to meet among friends – epicureans you might say – to enjoy the warm atmosphere of the place.

13 Celsius

content.title: 6,000 years of history at the Museum of Fine Arts

introduction.small: Exhibiting more than 50,000 works by van Dyck, Picasso and Pollock, the collection of the largest Texan museum is impressive.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: 6,000 years of history at the Museum of Fine Arts

paragraphs.text:
From the outside on Main Street, the Audrey Jones Beck Building (named after a major patron of the museum) may look stark. This concrete building was conceived by architect Rafael Moneo, winner of the 2006 Pritzker award, who supervised the construction of the new wing of the museum in 2000. This expansion was essential in housing the gigantic art collection it offers on display.

Both located in downtown Houston, the two main MFAH buildings are linked together by an underground passage. The Audrey Jones Beck Building shelters collections of Antique art, European works, photographs and American art up to the 1950s. Nearby, the Caroline Wiess Law Building exhibits African, Asian, American, Oceanian and Contemporary arts. In the same vicinity, other museums are also open to the public, mostly regarding decorative arts.

Museum of Fine Arts

content.title: Stay at the Hotel Indigo Houston at The Galleria

introduction.small: Enjoy a charming stay just steps from the Houston Galleria, the largest mall in the state of Texas.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Stay at the Hotel Indigo Houston at The Galleria

paragraphs.text:
The Hotel Indigo Houston at The Galleria welcomes you in the trendy Uptown District of Houston, rich in nightlife and renowned for its eclectic arts scene. This boutique hotel offers suites and rooms where design and space combine to form a unique environment. The hotel plays on colourful decoration, which gives it a trendy tone. The staff, who are warm and pleasant, are always anxious to meet your every need.

On the practical side, the hotel is situated close to the Galleria Mall, near the largest chain stores, and a wide variety of restaurants, attractions and parks. On the culinary side, the restaurant, The Crossroads Bar & Grill is a great place to relax and enjoy a glass of wine, accompanied by a succulent pizzetta. As a bonus, the hotel has free parking.

content.title: The Menil Collection: temple of Modern Art

introduction.small: Well known from art lovers, The Menil Collection shelters amidst a marvel of architecture an ensemble of major works of art, as well as temporary exhibitions from all over the world.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Menil Collection: temple of Modern Art

paragraphs.text:
Started in June 1987 under John and Dominique de Menil's impetus, The Menil Collection gathers in one place part of the couple's private collection (sculptures, paintings and photographs). And what a place!

 

The museum itself is an architectural masterpiece designed by Renzo Piano. The roofs and ceilings are conceived with curved profile tiles that, audacious design notwithstanding, allow for natural light regulation at any time of day. As a demanding collector, Dominique de Menil wanted that visits to the Museum be different every time as per light variations.
You can admire 20th century works by Magritte, Ernst, Klee, Matisse, Picasso and Cézanne, but also Jackson Pollock and Andy Warhol.
The Menil Collection is not just devoted to Modern Art as it also shelters items from Classical Antiquity, Byzantine and Medieval periods, as well as Arts of Africa.

The Menil Collection

77006 Houston

+1 713 525 9400

www.menil.org

content.title: In the middle of the Houston night

introduction.small: Whether in regular or live entertainment bars, country music gives way to more modern sounding genres : Jazz, Rock, R'n'B and even Hip Hop.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: In the middle of the Houston night

paragraphs.text:
If you plan for a night out in Houston, go for concerts in small bars and cafés, rather than usual clubs that close early in the night. As in many other fields, you're likely to be surprised by the variety of the musical movements. Some bars in the district of Montrose and The Heights welcome highly talented Texan singers and songwriters. For instance, you can still sometimes hear a couple of country music tunes at the Anderson Fair Retail Restaurant in Montrose or at the McGonigel's Mucky Duck, an Irish pub on Norfolk Street.

The Indie Rock scene is well-represented at Fitzgerald's and Dan Electro's Guitar Bar in The Heights. To listen to foreign artists, check the House of Blues program, or The Numbers'. The most eclectic venue is possibly the Warehouse Live, where you can hear everything from Blues to Rap and Pop Rock.
